column1: ğŸ”“ What does the public access modifier mean in a class?
column2:
ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Imagine a public notice board that everyone can see and write on.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Public properties and methods are accessible from anywhere â€” inside or outside the class.

ğŸ’» Example:
```ts
class MyClass {
public name: string = 'Default';
}

const obj = new MyClass();
obj.name = 'Hello';
console.log(obj.name); // Hello
```

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like your phone number you share openly â€” anyone can reach out.

column1: ğŸ”’ What does the private access modifier do?
column2:
ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Think of a diary locked with a key â€” only you can open it.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Private members can only be accessed within the class they are defined in. Not even subclasses can reach them directly.

ğŸ’» Example:
```ts
class MyClass {
private secret: string = 'hidden';
}

const obj = new MyClass();
console.log(obj.secret); // âŒ Error: Property 'secret' is private
```

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like your bank PIN â€” even your best friend canâ€™t see it.

column1: ğŸ” What does readonly do when used with public?
column2:
ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Like your birth certificate â€” visible but unchangeable.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Readonly properties can be read from anywhere, but cannot be reassigned after the object is initialized.

ğŸ’» Example:
```ts
class MyClass {
public readonly id: number;

constructor(id: number) {
this.id = id;
}
}

const obj = new MyClass(1);
obj.id = 2; // âŒ Error: Cannot assign to 'id' because it is a read-only property
```

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a serial number etched onto your phone â€” you can read it, but not change it.

ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Protecting your money from sneaky changes.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: By making _balance private, you ensure that only trusted methods within the class can change or read it, helping enforce data integrity.

ğŸ’» Example:
```ts
class BankAccount {
private _balance: number = 0;

addDeposit(amount: number) {
if (amount > 0) this._balance += amount;
}

getBalance(): number {
return this._balance;
}
}

const account = new BankAccount();
account.addDeposit(100);
console.log(account.getBalance()); // 100
```

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a vault â€” only trusted procedures can open it.

ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Like trying to peek into your parent's locked diary â€” not happening.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: No, because _balance is private to BankAccount. Even subclasses like StudentAccount can't access it directly.

ğŸ’» Example:
```ts
class BankAccount {
private _balance: number = 0;

protected getBalance(): number {
return this._balance;
}
}

class StudentAccount extends BankAccount {
showBalance() {
// return this._balance; // âŒ Error: '_balance' is private
return this.getBalance(); // âœ… Allowed via a protected method
}
}

const sa = new StudentAccount();
console.log(sa.showBalance());
```

ğŸ”„ Analogy: You canâ€™t open your parent's locked diary, but they might read from it to you.
Answer

ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Ever opened a window just to take a peek outside without changing anything?

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: A getter allows you to access the value of a private or protected property as if it were a normal public property â€” without exposing the actual property.

ğŸ’» Example:
class BankAccount {
  // Internal protected balance, not accessible directly from outside
  protected _balance: number = 100;

  // Getter to safely expose the balance value
  get balance(): number {
    console.log('Getter called: fetching balance...');
    return this._balance;
  }
}

const acc = new BankAccount();
console.log(acc.balance); // Output: Getter called: fetching balance... 100

// Trying to access _balance directly would cause an error:
// console.log(acc._balance); // Error: Property '_balance' is protected

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a peephole in a door â€” you can look, but not touch or change anything!

ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Imagine you're putting money into a vending machine by simply dropping it in.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: A setter lets you update a private or protected property from outside the class â€” with validation or logic if needed â€” using property-like syntax.

ğŸ’» Example:
class BankAccount {
  protected _balance: number = 100;

  // Setter to allow deposits with validation
  set deposit(amount: number) {
    if (amount <= 0) {
      console.log('Deposit amount must be positive.');
      return;
    }
    console.log(`Setter called: adding $${amount} to balance.`);
    this._balance += amount;
  }

  get balance() {
    return this._balance;
  }
}

const acc = new BankAccount();
console.log(acc.balance); // 100

acc.deposit = 50; // Setter called: adding $50 to balance.
console.log(acc.balance); // 150

acc.deposit = -20; // Deposit amount must be positive.
console.log(acc.balance); // 150 (unchanged)

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like depositing money into a bank ATM â€” you put in the amount, but the machine handles where it goes.

column1: ğŸ”’ Why use get and set instead of public methods?
column2:
ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Wouldn't it feel smoother to open your curtains instead of using a remote switch every time?

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Getters and setters make code cleaner and more natural to use, like accessing properties â€” but with the safety and control of methods.

ğŸ’» Example:
class BankAccount {
  protected _balance: number = 100;

  get balance() {
    return this._balance;
  }

  set deposit(amount: number) {
    if (amount <= 0) {
      console.log('Deposit must be positive');
      return;
    }
    this._balance += amount;
  }

  // Traditional methods for comparison
  addDeposit(amount: number) {
    if (amount <= 0) {
      console.log('Deposit must be positive');
      return;
    }
    this._balance += amount;
  }

  getBalance() {
    return this._balance;
  }
}

const acc = new BankAccount();

// Using getters/setters (property-like syntax)
acc.deposit = 100;
console.log(acc.balance);

// Using traditional methods (explicit method calls)
acc.addDeposit(50);
console.log(acc.getBalance());

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like smart home devices â€” behind the scenes itâ€™s complex, but you just tap a button.

ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Picture a museum: the artwork is visible to guests, but only curators can touch it.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: _balance is the protected internal data. balance (getter) safely exposes that data to the outside world.

ğŸ’» Example:
class BankAccount {
  // Protected property holding the actual value
  protected _balance: number = 500;

  // Getter to provide read-only access externally
  get balance(): number {
    return this._balance;
  }
}

const acc = new BankAccount();

console.log(acc.balance);  // 500 (read via getter)

// acc._balance = 1000; // Error: Property '_balance' is protected

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a protective glass over a cake â€” you can see it, but canâ€™t poke it directly!

ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Imagine a classroom whiteboard â€” shared by all students, not owned by one.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: A static property or method belongs to the class itself, not to instances. All objects share the same static value.

ğŸ’» Example:
class Counter {
  // Static property to track count shared by all instances
  static count: number = 0;

  // Static method to increment and return count
  static increment(): number {
    Counter.count++;
    console.log(`Count incremented to: ${Counter.count}`);
    return Counter.count;
  }

  // Instance method to show instance count, if needed
  showInstanceCount() {
    console.log(`Instance method can't access static count directly.`);
  }
}

Counter.increment(); // Count incremented to: 1
Counter.increment(); // Count incremented to: 2

const c1 = new Counter();
c1.showInstanceCount(); // Instance method can't access static count directly

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a scoreboard in a stadium â€” everyone sees the same score, no matter where they sit!

column1: ğŸ‘¯ Can each object have its own static value?
column2:
ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Can different TV remotes show different time if they're all showing the clock from the same cable box?

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: No! Static values are **shared** across all instances â€” changing one changes it for all.

ğŸ’» Example:
class Counter {
  static count: number = 0;

  static increment() {
    return ++Counter.count;
  }
}

Counter.increment(); // 1
Counter.increment(); // 2

const c1 = new Counter();
const c2 = new Counter();

// Even though c1 and c2 are different objects, static count is shared
console.log(Counter.count); // 2
console.log(c1.constructor['count']); // 2
console.log(c2.constructor['count']); // 2

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a shared Google Doc â€” all changes are instantly visible to everyone.

column1: ğŸš« Why can't we access static methods via instances?
column2:
ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: You donâ€™t ask your clone for a family name â€” you ask the family itself!

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Static members exist on the class, not on objects. Thatâ€™s why you must use ClassName.method() instead of object.method().

ğŸ’» Example:
class Counter {
  static increment() {
    console.log('Static increment method called.');
  }
}

const c = new Counter();

// âŒ This will cause an error or be undefined:
// c.increment(); // Error: Property 'increment' does not exist on type 'Counter'

// âœ… Correct usage:
Counter.increment(); // Static increment method called.

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like the rules of chess â€” you ask the book, not the pieces.

column1: ğŸ§  When should you use static in real projects?
column2:
ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: Ever used a calculator app that works the same for every user?

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Use static when the data or behavior is common across all instances â€” like counters, utility functions, config settings.

ğŸ’» Example:
class Utils {
  // Static method accessible without creating an instance
  static greet(name: string): string {
    return `Hello, ${name}! Welcome to the app.`;
  }

  // Static constant, shared config
  static readonly MAX_USERS = 1000;
}

console.log(Utils.greet('Sabbir')); // Hello, Sabbir! Welcome to the app.
console.log(`Max users allowed: ${Utils.MAX_USERS}`);

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a shared microwave in an office â€” everyone uses the same one.
Answer

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Imagine one word â€” 'play' â€” meaning different things to a child, a musician, and a footballer.

ğŸ“˜ Definition: Polymorphism allows different classes to define methods with the same name but different behaviors. It's like many shapes sharing the same interface but acting differently.

ğŸ’» Example:
class Person { getSleep() { console.log('8 hours'); } }
class Student extends Person { getSleep() { console.log('7 hours'); } }
class Developer extends Person { getSleep() { console.log('6 hours'); } }

const logSleep = (p: Person) => p.getSleep();

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like different instruments playing the same note â€” each sounds unique but follows the same musical key.

âœ¨ Emotional Hook: Wouldnâ€™t it be magical to call one method and get behavior based on whoâ€™s responding?

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Polymorphism helps in writing flexible and reusable code. You can call the same method on different types of objects without knowing their exact class.

ğŸ’» Example:
getSleepingHours(new Student());
getSleepingHours(new Developer());

This works because both are `Person` subclasses with their own `getSleep()` method.

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like using a single 'speak' command for different animals â€” dogs bark, cats meow, birds chirp.

column1: ğŸŸ¦ Polymorphism with Shapes â€” Whatâ€™s the Benefit?
column2:
ğŸ§  Emotional Hook: What if you could calculate area for ANY shape with just one function?

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: The `Shape` base class defines a `getArea()` method. Subclasses like `Circle` and `Rectangle` override it to provide specific calculations.

ğŸ’» Example:
class Circle extends Shape {
  getArea() { return Math.PI * r * r; }
}
class Rectangle extends Shape {
  getArea() { return height * width; }
}
getShapeArea(new Circle(10));

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like different people filling out the same form â€” same interface, unique answers.

column1: ğŸ” How does method overriding enable polymorphism?
column2:
ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Think of siblings with the same parent â€” each with their own way of celebrating their birthday!

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Method overriding allows child classes to redefine a method inherited from a parent class. This lets polymorphism work, giving you dynamic behavior at runtime.

ğŸ’» Example:
class Shape { getArea(): number { return 0; } }
class Circle extends Shape { getArea(): number { return Math.PI * r * r; } }

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like customizing a family recipe â€” same dish name, different flavors.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Imagine using a microwave â€” you press buttons without knowing how the electricity heats your food!

ğŸ“˜ Definition: Abstraction is the concept of hiding complex implementation details and showing only the necessary features.

ğŸ’¡ Use cases: Create blueprints (interfaces or abstract classes) that describe how things should behave, not how they work.

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like using a TV remote â€” you only need to know the buttons, not the circuitry inside.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Think of an interface like a contract â€” it says what must be done, but not how!

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: An interface in TypeScript defines a set of methods and properties a class must implement. Itâ€™s all about the 'what', not the 'how'.

ğŸ’» Example:
interface Vehicle {
  startEngine(): void;
  stopEngine(): void;
  move(): void;
}

class Car implements Vehicle {
  startEngine() { console.log('Starting engine'); }
  stopEngine() { console.log('Stopping engine'); }
  move() { console.log('Moving car'); }

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a job posting â€” it lists the responsibilities, but not how youâ€™ll complete them.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Imagine your favorite board game â€” the rulebook sets the structure, but each player can play their own way.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: An abstract class can have both abstract methods (no implementation) and normal methods (with implementation). Itâ€™s a partially completed blueprint.

ğŸ’» Example:
abstract class Car {
  abstract startEngine(): void;
  move() { console.log('Moving'); }
}
class Toyota extends Car {
  startEngine() { console.log('Starting Toyota'); } }

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a parent recipe that must be customized by each child â€” â€œmake curry,â€ but you decide the spices!

column1: ğŸ¤” Interface vs Abstract Class â€” Whatâ€™s the Difference?
column2:
ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Interfaces are like rules. Abstract classes are like templates with some rules already filled in.

ğŸ“˜ Summary:
  • âœ… Interface: Only declares method signatures, no code.
  • âœ… Abstract class: Can have both abstract and implemented methods.
  • âœ… A class can implement multiple interfaces but can only extend one abstract class.


ğŸ’» Example:
interface Flyable { fly(): void; }
abstract class Bird { abstract fly(): void; sing() { console.log('Chirp'); } }

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Interface = rulebook; Abstract Class = partly built house you must complete.
Answer

column1: ğŸ” What are Access Modifiers in TypeScript?
column2:
ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Ever wondered why you canâ€™t peek inside your teacherâ€™s gradebook, but you can see your own report card?

ğŸ“˜ Definition: Access modifiers control where class properties and methods can be accessed from:
  • public: Accessible from anywhere
  • private: Accessible only inside the class
  • protected: Accessible inside the class and its subclasses

ğŸ”„ Analogy: 1. Public = A public park â€” open to everyone.
2. Protected = Family-only hallway â€” shared among relatives.
3. Private = Your bedroom â€” just for you!

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Imagine a public park where everyone is welcome to stroll.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: Members marked public can be accessed anywhere â€” inside or outside the class.

ğŸ’» Example:
class BankAccount {
  public name: string;
  constructor(name: string) { this.name = name; }
}
const account = new BankAccount('Alice');
console.log(account.name); // âœ… Works anywhere

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a bustling town square â€” free and open to all!

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Think of your phoneâ€™s password â€” only you know it!

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: private members can only be accessed inside the class itself â€” not from subclasses or instances.

ğŸ’» Example:
class BankAccount {
  private balance: number = 100;
  private getBalance() { return this.balance; }
}
const acc = new BankAccount();
// acc.getBalance(); âŒ Error

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like your personal diary â€” locked and hidden just for you.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Like a secret family recipe passed down generations.

ğŸ“˜ Explanation: protected members are accessible inside the class and its subclasses â€” but not outside.

ğŸ’» Example:
class BankAccount {
  protected _balance: number = 100;
}
class StudentAccount extends BankAccount {
  printBalance() { console.log(this._balance); } // âœ… Accessible here
}
const acc = new StudentAccount();
// acc._balance; âŒ Error

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a family vault â€” shared among relatives but hidden from outsiders.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Imagine engraving your name on a trophy â€” once etched, it can't be changed!

ğŸ“˜ Definition: readonly makes a property immutable after initialization â€” either where itâ€™s declared or inside the constructor.

ğŸ’» Example:
class User {
  public readonly id: number;
  constructor(id: number) {
    this.id = id;
  }
}
const user = new User(123);
// user.id = 456; âŒ Error

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a sealed envelope â€” the address is fixed once sent!

column1: ğŸ—ï¸ What is Constructor Shorthand in TypeScript?
column2:
ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Want to do less work but still get full credit?

ğŸ“˜ Definition: You can declare and initialize class properties directly in the constructor parameters using access modifiers.

ğŸ’» Example:
class Product {
  constructor(public name: string, private price: number) {}
}
const pen = new Product('Blue Pen', 5);

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like ordering a combo meal â€” simpler, faster, same delicious result!

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: Ever used a smartphone without knowing how it works inside? Thatâ€™s encapsulation!

ğŸ“˜ Definition: Encapsulation hides internal details and exposes only whatâ€™s necessary for interaction.

ğŸ’» Example:
class BankAccount {
  private balance: number = 100;
  public deposit(amount: number) { this.balance += amount; }
}
const acc = new BankAccount();
acc.deposit(50); // âœ… Safe interaction

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a vending machine â€” you press a button, get a snack, but never see the mechanics inside.

ğŸ¯ Emotional Hook: When you drive a car, do you need to know how the engine works? Nope â€” thatâ€™s abstraction!

ğŸ“˜ Definition: Abstraction hides complex implementation details, showing only essential features.

ğŸ’» Example (interface):
interface Vehicle { move(): void; }
class Car implements Vehicle { move() { console.log('Moving'); } }

ğŸ’» Example (abstract class):
abstract class Animal { abstract makeSound(): void; }
class Dog extends Animal { makeSound() { console.log('Woof'); } }

ğŸ”„ Analogy: Like a TV remote â€” you know what each button does, not how the circuits inside work!
